Article.ArticleTitle: Production and characterization of monoclonal antibodies against the DNA binding domain of the RE1-Silencing Transcription factor.

Abstract.AbstractText: The use of monoclonal antibodies for detection of cellular biomarker during carcinogenesis provides new strategies for the diagnostic or prognostic of cancer in patients. The loss of the Restrictive Element 1-Silencing Transcription (REST) factor have been observed in previous molecular and immunological approaches in aggressive breast cancer, small cell lung cancer, liver carcinoma and colo-rectal cancer; however, in the clinic diagnostic there are not available monoclonal antibodies for REST recognition. The goal of this work was to design, produce and characterize monoclonal antibodies against the DNA Binding Domain (DBD) of REST suitable for immunoassays. We looked for conserved domains, and immunogenic and antigenic sites in REST structure through in silico analysis. For mice immunization, we used recombinant DBD of REST purified by affinity chromatography, and then hybridomes were generated by mouse spleen fusion with myeloma cells. Finally, for monoclonal antibody characterization we performed ELISA, Western Blot, Dot blot Immunocytochemistry and Immunoprecipitation assays. Results showed that DBD is conserved in REST isoforms and contains immunogenic and antigenic sites. We generated three clones producing monoclonal antibodies against DBD of REST, one of them specifically recognized native REST and was suitable for Immunocytochemistry in samples from patients.
